docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is New York. Who expects everything to work right? But if you feel overwhelmed by illegal dumping, double- and triple-parking, rats, spotty garbage collection, swarms of drug dealers or any other of a host of common annoyances, here are the places to complain.

headline.main: When Things Go Really, Really Wrong

docs.lead_paragraph: Janie H. Hunt works as a receptionist here at the Danville Regional Medical Center, and even though she is earning $5 an hour at the age of 55, she has never enjoyed a job more. "Look at me, just look at me," she said from behind her desk, beaming until the phone rang and she bolted to answer it.

headline.main: Hospital Helps Uninsured Regain Financial Health

docs.lead_paragraph: TODAY IN ALICE TULLY Hall, Wynton Marsalis faces one of his toughest challenges yet. And for a while at least, the magnetic jazz and classical trumpeter won't even be allowed to pick up his horn. He'll have to sit in the audience with everybody else and face the music, as the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presents the premiere of his new work for string quartet, "(At the) Octoroon Ball." By tackling the venerable quartet genre, Mr. Marsalis, who is the artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, joins the long line of composers who have dared to match wits with the likes of Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven, Bartok and Shostakovich. By inviting him to do so, the Chamber Music Society continues its 25-year tradition of commissioning works from leading composers of all stripes, from Barber to Boulez and beyond, while also browsing through the inexhaustible riches of three centuries' worth of chamber music.

headline.main: Out of the Comfort Zone, On to New Adventures

docs.lead_paragraph: INVESTORS are a soft touch for the pet business. As they scoop up shares of Petsmart, the superstore chain, or of Veterinary Centers of America, they often think fondly of their own cat or dog and don't fret overmuch about the economic fundamentals. But these sentimental favorites -- Pet smart sells at a hefty 97 times trailing earnings and Veterinary Centers commands 124 -- are hardly bargains. And the latest member of the litter is no exception.

headline.main: Eyeing a Veterinary Chain? Be Sure to Check the Teeth

docs.lead_paragraph: Unemployment Rate Jumps As Number of Jobs Falls The nation's unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a point, to 5.8 percent, in April and the number of new jobs fell for the first time in more than two years, as the slowdown in the economy spread to the job market. The most startling figure in the employment data was the 9,000 decline in payroll jobs. And for the second straight month, the number of factory jobs declined. Analysts regarded the numbers as the most definitive in a series of reports showing a sharp deceleration of the economy. Indeed, fears are being raised that the Fed's anti-inflation campaign may have been overly severe. Page 1. The unemployment rate in New York State increased to 6.8 percent and rose to 6.3 percent in New Jersey. In New York City, the rate was up slightly, to 8.6 percent. 38. U.S. and Japan Break Off Talks on Automotive Trade The United States and Japan said talks over trade in automobiles and auto parts had ended in failure. The Clinton Administration plans to decide what kinds of trade sanctions to impose on billions of dollars in Japanese goods imported into the United States. 1. Drive for Legal Overhaul Is Trimmed Senate Republicans scaled back their effort to limit damage awards in liability suits, hoping to attract enough votes for passage on Monday. The revised proposal would extend the damage cap in product liability suits but only to cases against businesses or government entities with fewer than 25 full-time employees. The revised measure would not cap punitive damages in medical malpractice cases. 10. Dow Falls 16 on Jobs Report The Dow industrials declined in a second day of erratic trading, falling 16.26, to 4,343.40, as the decline in new jobs, the first in more than two years, raised the prospect that corporate earnings would slump. 39. A rally in the bond market helped the dollar gain slightly against the major currencies. The dollar rose to 1.3730 German marks from 1.3710 marks on Thursday and edged up to 83.96 yen, from 83.80. 34. Group in Bid for Grace Unit An investment group of former W. R. Grace executives is teaming up with Constantine Hampers in his $3.5 billion bid to buy National Medical Care, W. R. Grace's health care subsidiary. The group, called Quad-C, is based in Charlottesville, Va., and is headed by Terrence Daniels, a former Grace vice chairman who led the acquisition of National Medical Care in 1984. 37. New York Fines Prudential Prudential Insurance has agreed to pay a $5 million fine for disregarding rules requiring that agents and the policy forms they use be approved by New York State. It was the biggest fine ever levied by the New York Insurance Department, but the department said there was little effect on consumers. 38. Trump and Pritzker Settle Feud Donald Trump, left, and Jay Pritzker have settled their long-running legal feud over the management of the Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York, which they jointly own and which the Pritzker family's Hyatt Corporation manages. People familiar with documents signed by both sides this week said the settlement cleared the way for renovations at the convention hotel near Grand Central Terminal. Mr. Pritzker said he hoped that work on the hotel "could begin soon." 37. Borrowing by Consumers Increases Consumer borrowing accelerated during March at the fastest pace since last summer. Led by a $6.7 billion increase in credit card use, installment borrowing rose 17.9 percent, to $13.8 billion. In February, consumer credit rose a revised $7.7 billion. 38. Nintendo Delays New Game Machine Nintendo of America confirmed that its Ultra 64 video game player would not be ready in time for Christmas. The company said it would unveil the machine in November, but not introduce it until April 1996. Analysts said the delay could hurt competitors nearly as much as it did Nintendo, because consumers may put off buying any machine until the Ultra 64 becomes available. 34.

docs.lead_paragraph: Very little has rattled Republican leaders since they took control of Congress four months ago, but their anxiety in recent days has been almost palpable. The reason is Medicare, and the growing furor over Republican plans to rein in spending on that 30-year-old health insurance program for the elderly. The danger in this issue was aptly summarized by a poll that was conducted by one of the Republican Party's top pollsters and was circulated on Capitol Hill this spring by the American Hospital Association, which had commissioned it. The poll found not only that the Medicare program was immensely popular but also that a majority of Americans believed it was a program their taxes had already paid for -- not, in other words, a gift from the Government.

headline.main: Congressional Memo; G.O.P. Feels the Heat. The Furnace: Medicare.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday sharply criticized a group of business leaders who have called for deeper concessions from New York City's labor unions as an alternative to drastic cuts in services, calling their proposals "quite harmful" to his efforts to balance the budget. Appearing before the trustees of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit watchdog group supported by businesses, Mr. Giuliani said he needed "realistic approaches" to help close the $3.1 billion budget gap for the fiscal year that begins in July. And he pointedly dismissed some of the commission's recommendations for changes in union work rules as "absurd."

headline.main: Mayor Criticizes Business Group's Budget Recommendations

docs.lead_paragraph: The stock market roared into record territory yesterday, pushed higher by a friendly bond market, good corporate earnings and additional signs of a cooling economy, factors that have fueled much of its breath-taking advance so far this year. While the Dow Jones industrial average surged by 44.27 points, to 4,373.15, yesterday's gains were in no way confined to blue-chip issues.

headline.main: Stocks Continue Their Surge, With Dow Advancing 44.27

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican Congressional leaders today invited President Clinton to join them in forging a bipartisan policy to control Medicare costs and keep the program solvent. But they found themselves struggling against White House assertions that their primary motivation was to balance the budget at the expense of the elderly. At a news conference today, Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, asked Mr. Clinton to meet them in the Capitol for a discussion of Medicare and asserted that spending on the health insurance program for the elderly could be separated from the rest of the budget. But they cut the news conference short and walked offstage under a barrage of questions on the relationship between Medicare spending and their plans to balance the budget while cutting taxes.

headline.main: Budgetary Matters Intrude On Call for Medicare Unity

docs.lead_paragraph: International A3-15 U.S. SHIFT ON CUBA The Clinton Administration ended 35 years of special treatment for Cuban refugees, saying it would start returning boat people after admitting a group being held at Guantanamo. A1 Cuban-Americans reacted with a mix of elation and dismay. A15 SERBS SHELL CROATIAN CAPITAL Rebel Serbs fired rockets on Croatia's capital, Zagreb, one day after the Croatian Government launched an offensive against Serbian-held territory. A1 LIBERIA'S UNHEEDED WAR After more than five years of a civil war that has killed well over 150,000 people, many Liberians wonder why their country's plight has attracted little international attention. A3 EUROPE COOL TO IRAN TRADE BAN The United States effort to get other countries to join a trade embargo of Iran faltered when leading European nations rejected the idea. A7 Russia is rethinking a sale to Iran of gas centrifuge equipment. A6 SUMMARY JUSTICE IN GAZA First reports from the Palestinian Authority's closed trials of Islamic militants indicate tribunals are handing down summary verdicts after short court proceedings. A8 PRESIDENTIAL DEBATE IN FRANCE Jacques Chirac, the conservative candidate, and his Socialist opponent, Lionel Jospin, emphasized economic issues in their first debate of the campaign. A9 A Rwanda military court is trying soldiers on murder charges. A12 Goiania Journal: Brazil's nuclear waste dump is open to tourists. A4 National A16-21, B6-8 2 ARRESTS, THEN DOUBT Federal agents in Missouri arrested two men thought be linked to the bombing in Oklahoma City, but within hours officials questioned the men's involvement. A1 The two men did not try to hide their identities or location. B6 SEARCH EFFORT CURTAILED With scant chance that any bomb victims are still alive inside the Federal Building, officials have scaled back the search effort. B6 BITTERSWEET MEMORIES The operator of the day-care center in the bombed Federal Building recalls tender moments before the blast that she believes was meant to kill the children in her care. B7 FORMIDABLE THREAT Experts said it was virtually impossible to prevent the construction of a bomb like the one that exploded in Oklahoma City. B7 A VICTORY FOR MURDOCH Handing Rupert Murdoch a victory, the Federal Communications Commission has decided not to force him to restructure his Australia-based media empire to comply with rules that limit foreign ownership of American television stations. A1 NOMINEE MAKES HIS CASE The nominee for Surgeon General, Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr., began his long-delayed Senate confirmation hearing by rejecting criticism of his medical and ethical standards. A1 THE PRICE OF PEACE The end of the cold war has brought peace but not prosperity to thousands of military-industry workers who have been laid off. A16 NO EVIDENCE OF TREASON The F.B.I. said its files contained no indication that architects of the World War II atomic bomb project spied for the Soviets.A17 REBUFF FROM WHITE HOUSE Republican Congressional leaders invited President Clinton to help them overhauling Medicare, but a White House official said the Republicans were simply looking for "political cover." A18 NO LIMIT ON 'PAIN AND SUFFERING' The Senate rejected an effort to limit the money that patients could collect in medical malpractice suits for "pain and suffering." A19 MUSEUM DIRECTOR QUITS The director of the National Air and Space Museum resigned, citing the dispute over the exhibit of the plane that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima 50 years ago. A19 WHITE HOUSE AIDE IMPLICATED An Arkansas banker has told Federal prosecutors that the deputy White House counsel told him to illegally conceal cash payments to Bill Clinton's 1990 campaign for governor, lawyers said. A20 EXECUTION IN PENNSYLVANIA A killer who begged the courts to let him die because "brain disease" made his life in prison hell was executed, becoming the first inmate put to death in Pennsylvania in 33 years. A21 Education Page B9 Clinton Administration supported a scholarship for blacks only. Class Notes: A new U.C.L.A. course on affirmative action hits home. Metro Digest B1 16 BRONX OFFICERS INDICTED Sixteen police officers from the 48th Precinct, including three sergeants, have been indicted for robbery, burglary, larcency, filing false police reports and insurance fraud. C13 Books: "Landscape and Memory," by Simon Schama. C19 Television: Doctor update. C20 A look at commercials. C20 Sports B11-17 Baseball: Great debut for rookie pitcher. B11 Living Section C1-10 The free nibble is alive and plentiful. C1 Mexican chefs embrace a lighter cuisine of old. Letters Bob Herbert: An urban primary. Thomas L. Friedman: Russian roulette. Simson Garfinkel: The road watches you. Melvin Jules Bukiet: When the Holocaust isn't news. Chronicle D22 Crossword C18
